entry.title: Statistical inference on multiple linear regression
entry.summary: statistical inference on multiple linear regression in Python using Numpy, Statsmodel and Sklearn. Implementation of model selection, study of multicolinearity and residuals analysis.
entry.content:

  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;

  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;

  margin: 0px;

  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent -40px, transparent 1px, transparent 1px, transparent 100%);
}

  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {

}
div.cell.selected {

  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 5px, transparent 5px, transparent 100%);
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}

  border-left-width: 0;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 7px, #E3F2FD 7px, #E3F2FD 100%);
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;

}

    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {

  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;

}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {

}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there

div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;

}

}

}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */

}

}

  /* .CodeMirror-lines */
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;

.highlight  { background: #f8f8f8; }

<h1 id="Introduction:-Inferential-Statistics---Multiple-Linear-Regression">Introduction: Inferential Statistics - Multiple Linear Regression<a class="anchor-link" href="#Introduction:-Inferential-Statistics---Multiple-Linear-Regression">¶</a></h1><p>This notebook builds upon the <a href="https://xavierbourretsicotte.github.io/stats_inference_1.html">first</a> notebook in the series and explores various implementations of <em>statistical inferences</em> on a <strong>multiple linear regression model. </strong></p>
<p>The notebook is divided into the following main sections:</p>
<ol>
<li>Introduction: notation, model description, formula, hypothesis</li>
<li>Inferential statistics: Implementation using Numpy and Pandas</li>
<li>Stability of the regression coefficients: multicolinearity, tolerance and VIF</li>
<li>Model Selection</li>
<li>Implementation using Statsmodel</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="Libraries">Libraries<a class="anchor-link" href="#Libraries">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [243]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">scipy.stats</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">stats</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">scipy.linalg</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sl</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>

<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython.core.display</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">HTML</span>
<span class="n">sns</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="c1">#Making seaborn the default styling </span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Dataset">Dataset<a class="anchor-link" href="#Dataset">¶</a></h2><p>The dataset is used to predict electricity consumption of housing units equipped with electrical heating, given data (variables) on the housing units.</p>
<p>There are $P = 6$ explanatory (or independent, exogeneous) variables $x_1, x_2,...x_p$ which are stored in the matrix $\mathbf{X}$:</p>
<ul>
<li>SURFACE: surface area of the housing unit in $m^2$</li>
<li>PERS: number of persons living in the housing unit</li>
<li>PAVILLON: 1 if the housing unit is a house, 0 for appartments</li>
<li>AGE: age of the unit</li>
<li>VOL: volume inside the housing unit in $m^3$</li>
<li>SBAINS: number of bathrooms</li>
</ul>
<p>The dependent (or endogeneous) variable $y$ is <em>"KW: number of KWH consumed during the month of January"</em> and is stored in the vector $Y$</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [244]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Manually create data set</span>
<span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">4805</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3783</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2689</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5683</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3750</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2684</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1478</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1685</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1980</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1075</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2423</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4253</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1754</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1873</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3487</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2954</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4762</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3076</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">130</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">123</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">98</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">178</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">134</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">78</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">95</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">78</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">110</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">130</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">73</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">87</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">152</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">128</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">180</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">124</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">7</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">65</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">18</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">77</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">34</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">7</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">8</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">25</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">56</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">27</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">22</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x5</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">410</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">307</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">254</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">570</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">335</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">280</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">180</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">250</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">237</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">180</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">286</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">351</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">220</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">217</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">400</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">356</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">520</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">330</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">x6</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Notation-in-matrix-form">Notation in matrix form<a class="anchor-link" href="#Notation-in-matrix-form">¶</a></h2><p>As the problem involves multiple variables, notation is simplified by using matrices. The following convention is used:</p>
<ul>
<li>$x_p$: sub-script $p$ is used to indicate the variable number. E.g. $x_1$ corresponds to SURFACE</li>
<li>$x_i$ sub-script $i$ indicates the observation number</li>
</ul>
<p>Hence we can define the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>vector $\mathbf{y}$ of size $[n \times 1]$ which contains the $n$ observations of the dependent variable</li>
<li>vector $\mathbf{\hat y}$ of size $[n \times 1]$ which contains the $n$ predictions of the model based on the regression coefficients</li>
<li>matrix $\mathbf{X}$ of size $[n \times (P+1)]$ which contains the observations $n$ of the $P$ variables, plus a column of $1s$ which will enable the calculation of the y-intercept</li>
<li>vector $\mathbf{b}$ of size $[(P+1) \times 1)]$ which contains the linear regression coefficients (or parameters)</li>
<li>vector $\mathbf{e}$ of size $[n \times 1)]$ which contains the residuals observed in the sample</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [245]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Image</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"/Users/User/Desktop/Data/Learning_Notebooks/images/mult_lin_reg_model.png"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[245]:</div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea output_execute_result">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"/>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Statistical-Model---Normally-distributed-errors">Statistical Model - Normally distributed errors<a class="anchor-link" href="#Statistical-Model---Normally-distributed-errors">¶</a></h2><p>We base the statistical inferences on a model with the following assumptions:</p>
<p>$\large Y_{i} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{1,i} + \beta_2 x_{2,i} + ... + \beta_p x_{p,i} + \epsilon_i$</p>
<ul>
<li>Errors $\epsilon$ are random variables which are independent, identically distributed with Expectation = 0 and variance = $\sigma^2$</li>
<li>Errors follow a normal distribution $\epsilon \sim N(0,\sigma^2)$ which can be written in matrix form as $\mathbf{\epsilon \sim (0, \sigma^2 I)}$</li>
<li>The $P$ dependent variables are assumed to be linearly independent, i.e. no variable is the result of a linear combination of other variables</li>
<li>$\beta_0, \beta_1,...,\beta_p$ are the unknown population parameters we are trying to estimate. $\beta_0$ is a constant term</li>
<li>$\mathbf{b} = B_0, B_1,...,B_p$ are estimators of the unknown population parameters and are therefore random variables. Their realization in a given sample are $b_0,b_1,...,b_p$</li>
<li>$Y_1,...,Y_n$ are random variables from the population, which are realized in a random sample as $y_1,...,y_n$</li>
<li>$\hat Y_1,...,\hat Y_n$ are random variables and are the values of the linear regression line, realization $\hat y_1,...$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{e} = e_1,...e_n$ are the observed residuals and are estimators of the true statistical errors</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Properties-of-the-Maximum-Likelihood-Estimators">Properties of the Maximum Likelihood Estimators<a class="anchor-link" href="#Properties-of-the-Maximum-Likelihood-Estimators">¶</a></h3><p>In can be shown that the estimators given by the Ordinary Least Square method and the Maximum Likelihood Method <em>coincide</em>, have the same properties and can be found in closed form. We present here the main results:</p>
<ul>
<li>Model: $\mathbf{Y = Xb + e}$ </li>
<li>Prediction: $\mathbf{ \hat Y = Xb}$</li>
<li>Residuals: $\mathbf{e = Y - \hat Y}$</li>
</ul>
<p>Estimators for the regression coefficients:</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{b = (X'X)^{-1}X'y}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{b}$ is non biased: $E(\mathbf{b}) = \mathbf{\beta}$</li>
<li>Covariance matrix of  $\mathbf{b}$:  $Var(\mathbf{b}) =  \mathbf{ \sigma^2(X'X)^{-1}  }$</li>
<li>Variance of parameter $B_p$: $\mathbf{\hat \sigma^2_{B_p} = \hat \sigma^2 [(X'X)^{-1}]_{p+1,p+1}   }$ i.e. the diagonal element +1 of the covariance matrix</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Hat-matrix-and-orthogonal-projection">Hat matrix and orthogonal projection<a class="anchor-link" href="#Hat-matrix-and-orthogonal-projection">¶</a></h3><p>Re-arranging the previous results we get:</p>
<p>$\mathbf{\hat y = Xb = X(X'X)^{-1}X'y = Hy }$</p>
<p>$\mathbf{H = X(X'X)^{-1}X' }$</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{H}$ is often called the hat matrix because it adds a "hat" to the vector $y$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{H}$ is symmetric and idempotent</li>
<li>$rank(\mathbf{H}) = rank(\mathbf{X})$</li>
<li>It is a orthogonal projection matrix, which projects the dependent variable into the orthogonal subspace generated by the dependent variables</li>
<li>The $i-th$ diagonal element of $\mathbf{H} = h_{ii}$ is the leverage of observation $i$</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Computing-the-expectation-and-variance-of-the-residuals:-$\mathbf{Y---Xb}$">Computing the expectation and variance of the residuals: $\mathbf{Y - Xb}$<a class="anchor-link" href="#Computing-the-expectation-and-variance-of-the-residuals:-$\mathbf{Y---Xb}$">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>Let $\mathbf{M = I - H = I - X(X'X)^{-1}X'}$ </li>
<li>Then $\mathbf{I = H + M}$ and $\mathbf{M = M' = MM = M'M}$ and $\mathbf{MH = 0}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{M}$ is symmetric and idempotent. It is an orthogonal projection matrix to $\mathbf{H}$</li>
<li>$Rank(\mathbf{M}) = n - P -1$</li>
</ul>
<p>Residuals can be written as a linear combination of $Y_i$:</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{e = y - Xb = y - Hy = (I - H)y = My}$</li>
</ul>
<p>Re-writing this as a function of the <em>true errors</em> $\epsilon$ (not residuals):</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{e = y - Xb = My = M(X\beta + \epsilon) = MX\beta + M\epsilon = 0 + M\epsilon}$ </li>
</ul>
<p>Computing the expectation and variance:</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{E(e) = E(y - Xb) = E(M \epsilon) = ME(\epsilon) = 0}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{Var(e) = Var(y - Xb) = Var(M \epsilon) = M Var(\epsilon) = \sigma^2 M = \sigma^2 (I - H) }$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{S^2_{n -P - 1} = \large \frac{(y - Xb)'(y - Xb)}{n - P - 1} = \frac{e'e}{n - P - 1}} = \large \frac{1}{n - P - 1}\sum_{i=1}^n (e_i)^2$ is an unbiased estimator of the variance of the error</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Implications-of-the-normality-hypothesis">Implications of the normality hypothesis<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implications-of-the-normality-hypothesis">¶</a></h3><p>As with the simple regression model, the assumption of normally distributed errors allows us to make inferential statements about the random variables. Recall that:</p>
<ul>
<li>$\mathbf{y \sim N(X\beta, \sigma^2I)}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{y - Xb \sim N(0, \sigma^2M)}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{b \sim N \left( \beta, \sigma^2 (X'X)^{-1} \right)}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{B_p \sim N \left(\beta_p, \sigma^2 [(X'X)^{-1}]_{p+1,p+1} \right)}$</li>
<li>$\large \mathbf{\frac{B_p - \beta_p}{\sigma^2 [(X'X)^{-1}]_{p+1,p+1}} \small \sim N(0,1) }$</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Decomposition-of-the-sum-of-squares-and-geometric-interpretation">Decomposition of the sum of squares and geometric interpretation<a class="anchor-link" href="#Decomposition-of-the-sum-of-squares-and-geometric-interpretation">¶</a></h3><p>The true errors $\epsilon$ are the difference between the values of $y$ and the true population mean $\bar y$, i.e. $\mathbf{\epsilon = y - \bar y = y - X\beta}$.</p>
<p>We can write the formula for the total sum of squares in multiple dimensions as:</p>
<ul>
<li>$SS_{Total} =  SS_{Residual} + SS_{Explained}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{ || y - \bar y ||^2 = ||y - \hat y ||^2 + ||\hat y - \bar y||^2 }$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{ || \epsilon^2 ||^2 = || y - Xb ||^2 + || Xb - X \beta ||}$</li>
<li>$\mathbf{ \epsilon' \epsilon = \epsilon'M\epsilon + \epsilon' H \epsilon }$</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [246]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Image</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"/Users/User/Desktop/Data/Learning_Notebooks/images/triangle.png"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[246]:</div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea output_execute_result">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"/>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Distributions-of-the-sides-of-the-triangle">Distributions of the sides of the triangle<a class="anchor-link" href="#Distributions-of-the-sides-of-the-triangle">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li><p>$\mathbf{ \epsilon' \epsilon } \sim \sigma^2 \chi^2_{n} $</p>
</li>
<li><p>$\mathbf{ \epsilon' M \epsilon } = \sum (Y_i - \hat Y_i)^2 \sim \sigma^2 \chi^2_{n - P -1} $</p>
</li>
<li><p>$\mathbf{ \epsilon' H \epsilon } \sim \sigma^2 \chi^2_{P + 1} $</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="Test-statistics-and-hypothesis-testing">Test statistics and hypothesis testing<a class="anchor-link" href="#Test-statistics-and-hypothesis-testing">¶</a></h2><h3 id="Student-T-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-parameter-$B_p$">Student T statistic for the test of significance of parameter $B_p$<a class="anchor-link" href="#Student-T-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-parameter-$B_p$">¶</a></h3><p>$\large \mathbf{\frac{B_p - \beta_p}{S_{B_p}} \sim T_{n-P-1}}$ where $S_{B_p} = S_{n - P -1}[(X'X)^{-1/2}]_{p+1,p+1}$</p>
<p>Under the null hypothesis the parameters (coefficients) are zero:</p>
<ul>
<li>$H_0: \beta_p = 0$</li>
<li>$H_1: \beta_p \neq 0$</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Fisher-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-the-model-as-a-whole:">Fisher statistic for the test of significance of the model as a whole:<a class="anchor-link" href="#Fisher-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-the-model-as-a-whole:">¶</a></h3><p>$\large \frac{\sum(\hat Y_i - \bar Y)^2 / P}{ \sum( Y_i - \hat Y_i)^2 / n - P - 1} = \frac{SS_{exp} / P}{SS_{Res} / n -P -1 } \sim F_{P,(n -P - 1)}$</p>
<p>Under the null hypothesis there is no linear relationship between the dependent and independent variables:</p>
<ul>
<li>$H_0: Y_i = \beta_0 + \epsilon_i$</li>
<li>$H_1: Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_1 + ... + \beta_p x_i + \epsilon_i$</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Fishier-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-nested-models">Fishier statistic for the test of significance of nested models<a class="anchor-link" href="#Fishier-statistic-for-the-test-of-significance-of-nested-models">¶</a></h3><p><strong>Definition</strong>: a model A is nested in model B if the parameters of model A are a subset of the parameters in model B. In other words if model A is a special case of model B.</p>
<p>Consider the following two models and corresponding null and alternate hypothesis:</p>
<ul>
<li>A sub-model $H_0 = \{ Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{1,i} + ... + \beta_r x_{r,i} + \epsilon_i\} $ which contains $r$ dependent variables</li>
<li>The complete model $H_1 = \{ Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{1,i} + ... + \beta_p x_{p,i} + \epsilon_i\} $ which contains all $p$ dependent variables where $p > r$</li>
<li>In the null hypothesis $H_0$ all $P - r$ coefficient of regression are considered to be null: $H_0 = \{ \beta_{r+1} = ... = \beta_P = 0 \} $</li>
</ul>
<p>The test statistic can be used to test the nullity of the $P-r$ coefficient of regression, effectively comparing the statistical significance of the the nested model and the complete model :</p>
<p>$\large F = \frac{ \left( (SS_{Exp} \ | \ H_1) - (SS_{Exp} \ | \ H_0) \right) / (P - r)  }{(SS_{Res} \ | \ H_1) / (n - P - 1)} \sim F_{(P-r),(n-P-1)}$</p>
<h3 id="Adjusted-R-squared">Adjusted R squared<a class="anchor-link" href="#Adjusted-R-squared">¶</a></h3><p>The R-squared value, or coefficient of determination is defined as usual:</p>
<p>$\large R^2 = \frac{SS_{Exp}}{SS_{Tot}}$</p>
<p>The adjusted R-squared takes into account the degrees of freedom of the model and allows to compare models with different numbers of dependent variables. It is an unbiased estimator of the coefficient of determination of the population when it is positive</p>
<p>$\large R_a = \frac{R^2(n-1) - P}{n - P -1}$</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Statistical-Inference:-Implementation-using-Numpy--and-Pandas">Statistical Inference: Implementation using Numpy  and Pandas<a class="anchor-link" href="#Statistical-Inference:-Implementation-using-Numpy--and-Pandas">¶</a></h1><h2 id="Custom-Python-class">Custom Python class<a class="anchor-link" href="#Custom-Python-class">¶</a></h2><p><em>Note that Statsmodel is used for probability calculations</em></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [277]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">multiple_linear_reg_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">object</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">'''Class used to bundle together the data, coefficients, parameters, and statistics </span>
<span class="sd">    of the simple linear regression model '''</span>
    
    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">__init__</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="sd">'''Initializing the dataset and the basic computed values:</span>
<span class="sd">        x,y : datasets</span>
<span class="sd">        n: number of observations </span>
<span class="sd">        x_bar, y_bar: means of variables</span>
<span class="sd">        s_xx, s_yy, s_xy: short hand notation, e.g. s_xx = sum(x - x_bar)^2 </span>
<span class="sd">        '''</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X_bar</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_bar</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">XX</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span>
    
        <span class="c1">#Attributes defined here but initialized in the other methods</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">H</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">M</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">e</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_hat</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2_a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_tot</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_n_p_1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_b</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S_b</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_values</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_p_values</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_value</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_p_value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
    
    
    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">inv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">XX</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">H</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">inv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">XX</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">M</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">identity</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">H</span>
        
        <span class="c1">#Predicted values and residuals</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_hat</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">@</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">e</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_hat</span>
        
        <span class="c1">#Sum of squares</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_tot</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_bar</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_hat</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_hat</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_bar</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">)</span>
        
        <span class="c1">#R squared and adjusted R-squared</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_tot</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2_a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="c1">#Variances and standard error of coefficients</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_n_p_1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_b</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">diag</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_n_p_1</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">inv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">XX</span><span class="p">))</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S_b</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sqrt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S2_b</span><span class="p">)</span>
        
    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">probabilities</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_values</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S_b</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_p_values</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">stats</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_values</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">2</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">))</span>
        <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_p_value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">stats</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_value</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">)</span>
        
        
<span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">multiple_linear_reg_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">probabilities</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Stability-of-the-coefficients-and-multicolinearity">Stability of the coefficients and multicolinearity<a class="anchor-link" href="#Stability-of-the-coefficients-and-multicolinearity">¶</a></h1><p>The standard deviation of $b_j$ is a good indicator of the stability of the estimation of the coefficients of regression.</p>
<p>Since $var \mathbf{(B) = \sigma^2(X'X)^{-1}}$, if the dependent variables $x_1,...,x_p$ are highly correlated, then the determinant of $\mathbf{X'X}$ will be close to zero and the inverse will have very high values on its main diagonal. It appears that a main source of instability in the estimation of $\beta_p$ is therefore the <em>multicolinearity</em> of the dependent variables.</p>
<h3 id="Tolerance-and-VIF">Tolerance and VIF<a class="anchor-link" href="#Tolerance-and-VIF">¶</a></h3><p>Two measures of multicolinearity between variables are the <em>tolerance</em> and <em>Variance Influence Factor (VIF)</em>.</p>
<ul>
<li>$Tol(x_p) = 1 - R^2_p$</li>
<li>$VIF(x_p) = \large \frac{1}{Tol(x_p)} = \frac{1}{1 - R^2_p}$</li>
<li>$R^2_p$ is the coefficient of determination (i.e. the R-squared) of the linear regression of $x_p$ on all the other predictors. </li>
</ul>
<p>In effect, this means running a regression model with $x_p$ as the independent variable and all other $x_1,...,x_{p-1}$ dependent variables as predictors. If $x_p$ is orthogonal to all other variables (i.e. covariance is zero) then $VIF(x_p) = 1$</p>
<p>It can be shown that the variance of a coefficient is a function of the VIF, namely:</p>
<p>$\hat \beta_{B_p} = \large \frac{\hat \sigma^2}{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_{ip} - \bar x_p)^2} \small \times VIF(x_p)$</p>
<p>Values where $Tol < .5$ and $VIF > 2$ are to be investigated for multicolinearity</p>
<h3 id="Eigenvalues,-Condition-Index-and-Condition-Number">Eigenvalues, Condition Index and Condition Number<a class="anchor-link" href="#Eigenvalues,-Condition-Index-and-Condition-Number">¶</a></h3><p>Other measures of multicolinearity are provided by the correlation matrix of the dependent variables. The correlation matrix is found by normalizing the matrix $\mathbf{X}$ and then computing $\mathbf{X'X}$.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Eigenvalues of the correlation matrix:</strong> each eigenvalue is linked to the correlation of a variable with the others. Printing the eigenvalues from largest to smallest helps visualize colinearity. In particular, eigenvalues close to zero point towards linear dependence. A value of 0 indicates perfect linear dependence, and therefore perfect colinearity</li>
<li><strong>Condition Index </strong>: the square root of the ratio between the largest eigenvalue and the eigenvalue associated to each variable. The condition index is equal to 1 if variables are perfectly independent, a large value > 30 highlights a collinearity issue. </li>
</ul>
<h3 id="What-to-do-in-cases-of-multicolinearity">What to do in cases of multicolinearity<a class="anchor-link" href="#What-to-do-in-cases-of-multicolinearity">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>Increase the sample size</li>
<li>Select a subset of dependent variables </li>
<li>Perform Principal Component Analysis and then regression on the result</li>
<li>Ridge regression</li>
<li>PLS regression</li>
<li>LASSO regression</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Calculating-the-colinearity-diagnostic-using-Numpy">Calculating the colinearity diagnostic using Numpy<a class="anchor-link" href="#Calculating-the-colinearity-diagnostic-using-Numpy">¶</a></h2><h3 id="Tolerance-and-VIF-using-the-class-defined-previously">Tolerance and VIF using the class defined previously<a class="anchor-link" href="#Tolerance-and-VIF-using-the-class-defined-previously">¶</a></h3><p>For each variable in the dataset (i.e. colunm p in matrix X), run the regression model with column p as the y-variable, and the remaining variables as the dependent predictors. For each regression model, calculate the R2 value and the associated tol / VIF. Ingore the columns of 1s which is only for the y-intercept</p>
<h3 id="Condition-index">Condition index<a class="anchor-link" href="#Condition-index">¶</a></h3><p>Use Numpy's built-in correlation coefficient function to calculate the correlation matrix. Compute the eigenvalues, sort them and calculate their ratio. <em>Note: not used in the printed result table</em></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [367]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">colinearity_diagnostic</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">'''Calculate the VIF, Tol and condition number for each variable in the dataset X, </span>
<span class="sd">    Note that the first column of X is assumed to be a column of 1s and is ignored</span>
<span class="sd">    These are measures of multicolinearity'''</span>
    <span class="c1">#Initialize arrays: does not apply to the 1st variable (intercept)</span>
    <span class="n">VIF</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">Tol</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">Eig</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">Cond_Index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">]</span>
    
    <span class="c1">#VIF and TOL: Loop through each variable of the X data matrix</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">p</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]):</span>
        <span class="n">tmp_X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">delete</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">p</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">tmp_y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="n">p</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="n">tmp_model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">multiple_linear_reg_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">tmp_X</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">tmp_y</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">tmp_model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">()</span>
        <span class="n">VIF</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">tmp_model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span><span class="p">))</span>
        <span class="n">Tol</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">tmp_model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    
    <span class="c1">#Eigenvalues and Condition Index. Rowvar parameter for column variables</span>
    <span class="c1">#Not used in the result</span>
    <span class="n">corr_matrix_X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corrcoef</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">:],</span> <span class="n">rowvar</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">Eig</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">eig</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">corr_matrix_X</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">Cond_Index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sqrt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">max</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Eig</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">Eig</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">VIF</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">Tol</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">Eig</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">Cond_Index</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Print-results-in-a-format-similar-to-SAS-outputs">Print results in a format similar to SAS outputs<a class="anchor-link" href="#Print-results-in-a-format-similar-to-SAS-outputs">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [370]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">print_results</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="c1">#Print results in a similar format to SAS output</span>
    
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Analysis of Variance'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="n">df1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'1. DF'</span><span class="p">:[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'2. Sum of Squares'</span><span class="p">:[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_tot</span><span class="p">],</span>
                              <span class="s1">'3. Mean Square'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_exp</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">SS_res</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">P</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">],</span> 
                              <span class="s1">'4. F Value'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_value</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'5. Pr > F'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">F_p_value</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="p">},</span> <span class="n">index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Model'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Error'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Corrected Total'</span><span class="p">])</span>
        
    <span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
    
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Model recap'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="n">df2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'Values'</span><span class="p">:[</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">y_bar</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">R2_a</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="p">},</span> <span class="n">index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Dependent Mean'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'R-square'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'Adj R-square'</span><span class="p">])</span>
        
    <span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df2</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
    
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Parameter Estimates'</span><span class="p">)</span>

Standard Error'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">S_b</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'3. t Value'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_values</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'4. Pr > |t|'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">b_t_p_values</span><span class="p">,</span>
                              <span class="s1">'5. Tolerance'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">colinearity_diagnostic</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'6. VIF'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">colinearity_diagnostic</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]},</span> <span class="n">index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'intercept'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'SURFACE'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'PERS'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'PAVILLON'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'AGE'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'VOL'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'SBAINS'</span><span class="p">])</span>
        
    <span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">df3</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="n">print_results</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="p">)</span>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<hr/>
<h1 id="Model-Selection">Model Selection<a class="anchor-link" href="#Model-Selection">¶</a></h1><p>When is it useful to select a sub-model (or nested model) instead of the complete one?</p>
<ul>
<li>When certain dependent variables do not contribute to the model</li>
<li>When variables are highly colinear</li>
<li>Moreover, in cases of similar R2 values, a simpler model (i.e. with fewer variables) is generally preferred to a more complex one </li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Step-by-Step-approach:">Step by Step approach:<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-by-Step-approach:">¶</a></h3><p>Comparing all models to each other would result in $2^p$ possible combinations which is unfeasable in most cases. Instead use a step by step approach. There are three main approaches that can be used:</p>
<ul>
<li>Forward selection: start with a simple regression and add new variables</li>
<li>Backward elimination: Start with the complet model and remove variables</li>
<li>Stepwise: Start with a simple regression, add new variables and remove already existing variables at each step (based on pre-defined set of criteria) </li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Forward Selection approach </strong> - Which variable select at each step ?</p>
<ul>
<li>Step 1: Select the variable that has the highest correlation with the $y$ variable. </li>
<li>Step 2: Calculate the $p-1$ F statistics that compare the models between all variables</li>
<li>Step 3: Select the variable with the highest F statistic (as long as the p-value is smaller than a pre-defined level SLENTRY)</li>
<li>Repeat until there are no longer any variables that are statistically significant given the pre-defined level SLENTRY</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Coefficient-of-Mallows">Coefficient of Mallows<a class="anchor-link" href="#Coefficient-of-Mallows">¶</a></h3><p>Given a complete model with P parameters, the coefficient of Mallows allows to measure the quality of the nested model with $r<P$ parameters.</p>
<p>$C_p = \frac{SS_{Res-r}}{\hat \sigma^2} - (n - 2r)$</p>
<ul>
<li>$SS_{Res-r}$ is the sum of square of the residuals in the nested model with $r$ parameters</li>
<li>$\hat \sigma^2$ is the estimate of $\sigma^2$ in the complete model with $p$ parameters </li>
</ul>
<p>According to Mallows, a model with $r$ parameters is satisfactory if the value of $C_p \approx r$ or less. The higher the value of $C_p$ the more uncertainty there is on the estimations</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Implementation-of-model-selection-in-Python-(to-be-completed)">Implementation of model selection in Python (to be completed)<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implementation-of-model-selection-in-Python-(to-be-completed)">¶</a></h2><p>To be continued...</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/avinashbarnwal/Python-Stepwise-Regression">https://github.com/avinashbarnwal/Python-Stepwise-Regression</a></p>
<p><a href="https://datascience.stackexchange.com/questions/24405/how-to-do-stepwise-regression-using-sklearn/24447#24447?newreg=73e38e7b7b694b7fb595e3f81404da79">https://datascience.stackexchange.com/questions/24405/how-to-do-stepwise-regression-using-sklearn/24447#24447?newreg=73e38e7b7b694b7fb595e3f81404da79</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">

<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Implementation-of-Multiple-Linear-Regression-using-Statsmodel">Implementation of Multiple Linear Regression using Statsmodel<a class="anchor-link" href="#Implementation-of-Multiple-Linear-Regression-using-Statsmodel">¶</a></h1>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [374]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">statsmodels.api</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">sm</span>
<span class="c1">#Fit the model and print output</span>
<span class="n">lm2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sm</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">OLS</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">Data</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lm2</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>

<h3 id="Influence-study">Influence study<a class="anchor-link" href="#Influence-study">¶</a></h3>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">

<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Creating the influence object from the OLS results</span>
<span class="n">influence</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get_influence</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="c1">#Cooks distance for the x observations</span>
<span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">influence</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">cooks_distance</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1">#Leverage values for the x observations</span>

</pre></div>

entry.title: Statistical inference on simple linear regression
entry.summary: Implementation of statistical inference in Python using Numpy, Statsmodel and Sklearn. Detailed breakdown of the formulae used and main assumptions behind the model. Some nice graphs on leverage and influence of observations.
entry.content:
<style type="text/css">/*!
*
* IPython notebook
*
*/
/* CSS font colors for translated ANSI colors. */
.ansibold {
  font-weight: bold;
}
/* use dark versions for foreground, to improve visibility */
.ansiblack {
  color: black;
}
.ansired {
  color: darkred;
}

  color: darkgreen;
}
.ansiyellow {
  color: #c4a000;
}
.ansiblue {
  color: darkblue;
}
.ansipurple {
  color: darkviolet;
}
.ansicyan {
  color: steelblue;
}
.ansigray {
  color: gray;
}
/* and light for background, for the same reason */
.ansibgblack {

}

  background-color: red;
}
.ansibggreen {
  background-color: green;
}
.ansibgyellow {
  background-color: yellow;
}
.ansibgblue {
  background-color: blue;
}
.ansibgpurple {
  background-color: magenta;
}
.ansibgcyan {
  background-color: cyan;
}
.ansibggray {
  background-color: gray;
}
div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent -40px, transparent 1px, transparent 1px, transparent 100%);
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #90CAF9;
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #ababab;
  border-left-width: 0px;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 5px, transparent 5px, transparent 100%);
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-width: 0;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 7px, #E3F2FD 7px, #E3F2FD 100%);
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;
  border-left-width: 0px;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #66BB6A -40px, #66BB6A 5px, transparent 5px, transparent 100%);
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  background: #eaeaea;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.unrecognized_cell > div.prompt {
    display: none;
  }
}

  /* avoid page breaking on code cells when printing */
}
@media print {
  div.code_cell {
    page-break-inside: avoid;
  }
}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {
  page-break-inside: avoid;

  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;

  display: -moz-box;

}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {
  color: #303F9F;
  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  padding: 0.4em;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. We need the 0 value because of how we size */
  /* .CodeMirror-lines */
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
